results.title: Max Harris
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
As a founder of the “Angry Penguins”, Max Harris was at the forefront of the modernist movement in Australian poetry. He recalls the ferment in the artistic community as writers, painters and musicians struggled to find an authentic Australian voice and the uproar surrounding the Ern Malley controversy. Harris remembers his friendship with Sydney Nolan and the journey they made together which inspired the artist to paint his Ned Kelly series. A poet, author, publisher and social commentator, Max Harris gives a unique overview of a vital period in Australian cultural history.

results.title: John Morrison
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
John Morrison remembers his childhood in Sunderland, England, and how his ambition to write and travel brought him to Australia. A basic wage earner all his life, Morrison wrote prolifically in his spare time and used his work experiences in the bush, as a council worker and on the Melbourne waterfront, as background for his stories. He recalls his association with the trade union press and the Communist Review. A member of Realist Writers, he speaks of his friendship with Frank Davidson and Alan Marshall.

results.title: Sumner Locke Elliot
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Filmed in New York, December 1985. Sumner Locke Elliott recalls the characters and events of his youth which inspired his autobiographical novels. He began his career as an actor at the Independent Theatre in Sydney and went on to write and peform for radio. In 1948 Elliott left Australia and settled permanently in New York where he wrote television plays and later novels. He discusses different attitudes in Australia and America and the changes he has seen take place in American society.

results.title: Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II
results.brief_description: The second series of Archival Film Programs on Australian writers contains minimally-edited interviews with writers at home and at ease. We listen to their anecdotes, personal philosophies and are given a rare insight into their influences and motivations. These archival interviews are unique slices of social history and provide a picture of early Australia.

results.title: Dorothy Green
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Poet, journalist, author and academic, Dorothy Green speaks of her early childhood in England. She recalls the atmosphere of Sydney University in the 1930’s and her early success as a poet which led to a career in journalism. Green worked as a teacher and university lecturer in 1972, a grant enabled her to devote herself to writing. Green reads and discusses several of her poems and speaks of her spiritual beliefs and attitudes towards death. Interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Joan Lindsay
results.creator_credit: Ian McKay, Australia Council and AAV Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
In this interview with John Taylor, Joan Lindsay speaks about her experiences as an art student at the National Gallery School in Melbourne and her decision to become a writer. She talks about her marriage to the painter Daryl Lindsay. Lindsay describes the process of writing her novel, “Picnic at Hanging Rock”, and her preoccupation with time as a theme. Related to both the Boyd and Lindsay families, she gives a unique insight into the personalities of some of Australia’s leading artists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian McKay, Australia Council and AAV Australia

results.title: Olaf Ruhen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch, author Olaf Ruhen recalls a life travelling throughout Australia and the South Pacific gathering materials for his books. He speaks of his love of the sea and his affinity with the Tongan people. Ruhen recalls his friendship with the painter, Albert Namatjira. A visit to a writers’ conference in New York inspired Ruhen to create a forum for Australian authors, the Australian Society of Authors.

results.title: Joan Sutherland in concert
results.creator_credit: Phillip Booth, Brian J Smith, Western Australian Opera Company and TVW Enterprises
results.brief_description: Dame Joan Sutherland, “La Stupenda”, accompanied by her husband/arranger and renowned pianist, Richard Bonynge, gives an outstanding performance with a program that is rich and varied from the dramatic to the light-hearted. This full-length recital was recorded at the Perth Concert Hall on 9 March 1982 for television.

results.title: Gold fever
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass, Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: They came to get rich quickly and escape poverty in their homelands, but what they found was not always wealth. This program looks at life on the goldfields and discusses some of the problems that the diggers encountered. Sovereign Hill at Ballarat is featured.

results.title: Shinjuku Thief Remixes
results.brief_description: Supported by the City of Melbourne COVID-19 arts grants, this project engaged composers, sound designers and video editors to experiment and remix ACMI archive footage. A bold piece of music inspires a conceptual pairing from the collection, the elements of which are then carefully assembled into a microstructural puzzle of tight gestural relationships.
